Hello everyone!

GSoC '19 results are out. Every year a bunch of students from IIT Kharagpur get selected in GSoC and spread the word of Open Source. We look forward to getting the list of the selected students. Help us in aggregating the number of selections by filling the form. Note that your name can be kept private on request, so feel free to share your details.

Timeline:

- Phase 1 - Exploration: May 1st to May 5th 
- Phase 2 - Contribution: May 6th to July 28th 
- Phase 3 - Submission: July 28th to July 31st

We thank everyone for attending the event, ElasticSearch: You Know, For Search, and making it a huge success. We had the opportunity to have Aravind Putrevu as our guest speaker, who is a Developer Advocate at Elastic. 

He shared his experience with us and taught us about the state of the art Elastic Search, one of the most widely used distributed, RESTful search and analytics engine.

Please find the slides of the event at https://noti.st/aravindputrevu/3ngeiZ/elasticsearch-you-know-for-search

Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS, with help of Elastic, is organizing a talk-cum-demo session on ElasticSearch. The talk will provide an introduction to ElasticSearch; how to use it, where to use it and a quick demo of the same.

ElasticSearch is the most dynamic piece of technology at the moment, revolutionizing the way websites provide search and is an outstanding skill to learn since everyone is migrating to ElasticSearch.

Venue: V4, Vikramshila
Time: 6:30 PM
Date: 6th April, Saturday

TL;DR Elastic Is Coming!

ElasticSearch by Elastic is the most buzzing tech in the 
search industry, and hence, we stopped to ask each other at Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS, "What Is Elastic Search? And What Are We Cooking?"

And also why Google says, "Use ElasticSearch, not Google Site Search"?

Applications for Google Summer of Code 2019 is now open!
Application deadline is Tuesday, April 9 at 18:00 UTC.
This is the time you should prepare a draft proposal and share it with your mentor for review. Also, getting the proposal reviewed by senior/batchmate who have gone through this is a good idea.
https://opensource.googleblog.com/2019/03/accepting-student-applications-for.html

Here is an Open Source Summer internship opportunity for women and non-binary coders.  Rails Girls Summer of Code is a global fellowship program to bring more diversity into Open Source.

Students receive a three-month scholarship to work on existing Open Source projects and expand their skill set. Working in two-person teams, students are supported by a mentor directly involved with the Open Source project, as well as independent coaches with extensive developer experience.

Application procedure and details can be found at-
https://railsgirlssummerofcode.org/

The mentor organisations for the 15th year of Google Summer of Code has been released: https://summerofcode.withgoogle.com/organizations/

The most successful applications come from students who start preparing and interacting with the organisations now.  You can start by watching the short video at https://youtu.be/YN7uGCg5vLg .

It is highly recommended you go through the Student Guide (https://google.github.io/gsocguides/student/) and the Official FAQs at https://developers.google.com/open-source/gsoc/faq. Most, if not all of your queries may be addressed by them. 

For the rest, you can refer https://github.com/OrkoHunter/gsoc-FAQs [basic queries about GSoC] and https://thealphadollar.github.io/experience/2018/12/03/how-i-prepared-for-gsoc-18.html [a time-stamped GSoC experience]

All the Best!

An opensource internship opportunity for exclusively for women (both cis and trans), trans men, and genderqueer people. 

Outreachy provides three-month internships to work in Free and Open Source Software (FOSS). Interns are paid a stipend of $5,500 and have a $500 travel stipend available to them. Outreachy internship projects may include programming, user experience, documentation, illustration and graphical design, or data science. Interns often find employment after their internship with Outreachy sponsors or in jobs that use the skills they learned during their internship.

This is the season in KGP when societies and clubs elect their new Governors/Executives. We did too. We realized that the traditional model of members presenting their Statement of Purpose does not help in determining the leaders. We revamped the model into something, which we call "Governance Review Week".

It is a week dedicated to the Governance of KOSS.

Our intention behind organizing the Governance Review Week is to help the core team members measure their level of involvement in KOSS. The week also promotes open discussions between Seniors and the Core team members. We want each one of our members to be frank with their batchmates as well as seniors in sharing their opinions and perspective on every aspect of KOSS.

We also review how KOSS performed as a team in the past year. We identify our problems and discuss solutions. We want to make sure we eliminate all forms of toxicity from KOSS (It can be habits of how we do things, or some Core Team members themselves.)

Last year, Technology Literary Society - TLS, IIT Kharagpur adapted into having a similar Governance Review Week, and it generated a lot of value. You can read more about our process - https://github.com/kossiitkgp/docs/blob/master/community/governance-review-week.md

Results of Freshers Selections

For the past week, we were in the process of recruiting people who will take Kharagpur Open Source Society forward in the upcoming academic session. Buoyed by the participation of current 1st-year students, we have rigorously vetted and discussed each person who interviewed with us or filled the selection forms. Having said this, we believe that any selection process(including our’s) should not be considered as the sole criteria to judge one’s own self-worth as a programmer. Each one of us is a diamond underneath the surface. But, there were some whose answers and experiences that caught our attention

KOSS heartily welcomes the following students into the family. 
1. Aman Verma
2. Hemanth Kumar Uppada
3. Shubham Mishra
4. Raj Gupta
5. Debajyoti Dasgupta 
6. Anjay Goel
7. Priyanshu Kumar
8. Parth Paradkar
9. Pankaj Kumar
10. Mukul Mehta
11. Raghavendra Kaushik
12. Soumyajit Chakraborty

Kharagpur Open Source Society is proud to announce its new Executive batch:

Our new Executive Heads are -
1. Aditya Vikram Singh
2. Arnav Tiwari
3. Ayush Kaushal
4. Navaneeth Suresh
5. Taapas Agrawal
6. Yash Sharma

And our new Executive Members are -
1. Aaryan Bhagat
2. Anushka Shukla
3. Gaurav Goyal
4. Nikhil Choudhary
5. Pankhuri Saxena
6. Piyush Ranjan
7. Ritik Kumar
8. Shivam Kumar Jha
9. VIvek Raj

We had a very structured Governance Review Week and we came up with the following decision. It was the second year of this process and we have learnt a lot. 
We shall be sharing our procedure once it is written properly. 

We wish them all the very best! Cheers!

message:
"It is not an overstatement to say that Go will be the server language of the future."

Go, is an Open Source Programming language created at Google, created with system design in mind. It has amazing support for concurrency. It is statically typed which enables it to gain speed comparable to C/C++ but with the ease of dynamic language syntax. 

Time: 10am to 1pm
Venue: NR223

*Prerequisite - Basic programming knowledge in any knowledge should be sufficient.

To read more on why you should learn Go refer - https://bit.ly/2W5Qxt7

Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS shared their post. Karate in Action - build and test HTTP REST APIs in minutes In this hands-on workshop - you will get to experience what developing real-world web-services looks like. Armed with only a Java Runtime Environment, a text-editor and a web-browser - you will be able to create and deploy a usable REST API - and see it working within a web-browser. You will be able to compare and contrast Karate's approach with frameworks that you may be used to such as NodeJS or Flask. We will also explore a couple of public API-s while writing tests for them. Pre-Requisites: - Java or JS knowledge is good to have but not mandatory. - JDK8 (has to be 8, NOT 9 or above, take the latest version): https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk8-downloads-2133151.html - Maven: http://maven.apache.org/ - Git - make sure you can "git clone" and run this project: https://github.com/ptrthomas/karate-gatling-demo - which will ensure that you have everything needed for this workshop Register at : https://kwoc.kossiitkgp.org/summit

message:
Karate in Action - build and test HTTP REST APIs in minutes

In this hands-on workshop - you will get to experience what developing real-world web-services looks like. Armed with only a Java Runtime Environment, a text-editor and a web-browser - you will be able to create and deploy a usable REST API - and see it working within a web-browser. You will be able to compare and contrast Karate's approach with frameworks that you may be used to such as NodeJS or Flask. 

We will also explore a couple of public API-s while  writing tests for them.

Pre-Requisites:

 - Java or JS knowledge is good to have but not mandatory.
 - JDK8 (has to be 8, NOT 9 or above, take the latest version): https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk8-downloads-2133151.html
- Maven: http://maven.apache.org/
- Git
- make sure you can "git clone" and run this project: https://github.com/ptrthomas/karate-gatling-demo - which will ensure that you have everything needed for this workshop

Register at : https://kwoc.kossiitkgp.org/summit

This workshop can be a  stepping stone for students who want to pursue a career in Software Development, AI or Data Science.

Date: 19th Jan 2019
Time: From 10 AM - 1 PM

"I was addicted to hacking, more for the intellectual challenge, the curiosity, the seduction of adventure; not for stealing, or causing damage or writing computer viruses." :- Kevin Mitnick

The workshop will have both hands-on and Theoretical explanation. It will start with how basic web-apps work & end with how to find vulnerability and expose data in apparently secure web-app. We will discuss safe coding patterns and what not to do while writing a web-app. You are highly encouraged to attend Javascript workshop to get a better understanding of Web app.

If you ever
- wanted to see if Mrs. X/Mr. Y has liked your Instagram post or not but do not have enough patience to scroll through all the likes
- wanted to invite all your friends to a Facebook event because your seniors wouldn't let you go without it and you are sick of clicking on individual names
- wanted to filter out the old movies from IMDB Top 250 list so that you can have a list of new and good movies

then you are in luck. KOSS is organizing JavaScript workshop in 19th Jan from 10AM to 1PM at NR 223. 

We would be covering basics of JavaScript + a live walkthrough example of how you achieve all those tasks very easily leveraging the power of Web and JavaScript and a lot more.

This workshop would certainly make your life easier :) (and make you a better stalker)

*Basic programming knowledge in any language is highly recommended for this workshop.

- Dhiraj

Kharagpur Open Source Society (KOSS) is happy to announce the second edition of the Open Source Summit (https://kwoc.kossiitkgp.org/summit) in association with Kshitij'19 to be held on 19th and 20th January.

Below is the schedule for workshops and talks - 

Day 1,19th Jan:
- 10 am to 1 pm
  - Python: NR 221
  -  JavaScript: NR 223
Prerequisites for the above courses: Basic programming knowledge in any language.  
- 2 pm to 5 pm
Talk cum Workshop by Peter Thomas, Intuit: NR 221
Mr. Peter Thomas is a distinguished engineer at Intuit who will be giving a hands-on workshop and talk about API testing and Karate.

Day 2, 20th Jan:

- 10 am to 1 pm
 - Business Analytics/Data Science Workshop: NR 221.
One should have basic python knowledge for this workshop.
 - Go Workshop: NR 223
- 2 pm to 4 pm  
 - Hacking and Web Security: NR 221
- 4 pm to 5 pm
 - Talks: NR 221

Check out https://kwoc.kossiitkgp.org/summit to know more

Gear up for this weekend as KOSS brings to you an awesome opportunity to learn a bundle of awesome stuff.

Happy coding!

Hey There,
Greetings from KOSS.
Now that you are done with your End Semester exams, we are conducting a short Intro Seminar on Kharagpur Winter of Code for the people in the college campus.

Time: 5:40 PM to 8 PM
Date: November 29, 2018 | Thursday

We will be giving a brief overview of Version Control systems and Linux (So you should be bringing your laptops).

We'll also give you a short overview on How to Get Started with Open Source contributions via GitHub which would help you get started with the Winter Of Code'18.

If you haven't registered for KWoC: http://kwoc.kossiitkgp.org

Hope to see you there!
Kharagpur Open Source Society

If you want to collaborate on projects with others, the knowledge of a Version Control System is a must. To help you get started with collaborative development and Open Source, Kharagpur Open Source Society is conducting a workshop on Git and Github.

Time: 2 PM
Venue: NC 231
Date: 7th October 2018 (Sunday)

Please register at http://bit.ly/kossgit
This will help us in sending you resources after the workshop.

In this workshop, we will teach you the basics of Git as a version control software, and we will tell you how to actually contribute to projects on Github. There will be a hands-on session too, where you will learn actually to contribute to real software.

Note for Windows users: Please install Git Bash before coming to the workshop. 

Download link (for Windows users only): https://github.com/git-for-windows/git/releases/download/v2.19.0.windows.1/Git-2.19.0-32-bit.exe

People who want to take part in Hactoberfest and don't know where to begin, this is your golden choice.
Also if you aspire to take part in the upcoming Kharagpur Winter of Code in December or other programs like Google Summer of Code / Rails Girls Summer of Code/Outreachy the knowledge of Git and GitHub will be crucial.

The time of the year when you can earn a free T-Shirt. Yes, it's October and we are talking about Hactoberfest.

The deal: Send at least 5 Pull Requests to ANY publicly hosted repository on GitHub.

New to Git/GitHub? 
Don't worry, we are going to conduct a workshop on Git and GitHub soon, stay tuned to the page for updates regarding that.

So, go the "Open Sorcerers" way and get an exclusive "Open-Sorcerers" T-Shirt delivered to you.
Don't forget to take your friends along with you. Spread the word! Open Source FTW!
Happy Hacking.
Find out more at https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/

Having a UNIX like OS is crucial for every programmer. We are organizing an Ubuntu Install Fest, an opportunity to get Linux installed on your PC if you have not already done it.

Date: 2nd October 2018
Time: 2 PM to 6PM
Venue: Room F236, Main Building

Bring out the open source geek in you by switching to Linux as a standalone OS, or get it dual booted alongside Windows.

Note: Please download a copy of Ubuntu 18.04 LTS (https://www.ubuntu.com/download/desktop). Backup all your important files and don't forget to bring a Pen Drive along with your laptop. Ensure there is around 100 GB free space on your PC. Make sure your laptop is fully charged for the installation to complete smoothly.
Dual boot instructions: https://wiki.metakgp.org/w/How_to_install_Ubuntu_as_Dual_Boot
PS: If you can't download Ubuntu or bring a pen drive with you, just come with your laptop, we'll have a few spare pen drives.

Hey there,
Just like every year, this weekend, KOSS is going to organise Python Programming classes. Python is a general-purpose language, which means it can be used to build just about anything. Python helps you to work in various fields such as - Data Mining, Machine Learning, Data Analysis, Web Development and more seamlessly.

These programming classes can be stepping stones for students who want to pursue a career in Software Development or Data Science. The classes are going to be conducted on 1st and 2nd of September '18 (Saturday and Sunday).  Event details are as follow -

Venue: Nalanda NC-231
Date: 1st-2nd Sep 2018
Time: From 3 PM
Register at - http://bit.ly/kosspc18

Make sure you bring your laptop with you. Also, it would be great if you have Python pre-installed.
Download python from - https://www.python.org/downloads/ (3.x versions)

If you are new to programming, don't worry we have got that covered for you.

message:
Hello Freshers,

We are Kharagpur Open Source Society. We are a group of open source and coding enthusiasts. Every year KOSS plans to hold events for familiarising students with UNIX tools, Linux environment, Git Development Workflow, besides conducting workshops on Python programming, Application development and hackathons.

KOSS also conducts Kharagpur Winter of Code which is a month-long program focused on introducing students into open source software development during the month on December.

This year too we would be organising events like Git Workshop, Ubuntu Install Fest, Introduction to Python Programming and more. Stay tuned and turn on notifications for posts from KOSS so that you do not miss any of our events.

Want to be a part of KOSS?
KOSS's introductory seminar is conducted during the Spring semester which is followed by selections for 1st-year students. 
Attend our Tutorials, Workshops and keep exploring the exciting world of Open Source.

Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS shared GirlScript Delhi's photo. #BeAMentor or #SubmitYourProject We're thrilled to announce that 1st edition of GirlScript Summer of Code ( gssoc.tech ) is about to reach 1000 students milestone! 🎆 1000 developers across India will take part in this 3 month long open source journey with GirlScript. Call for mentors is still open to guide these developers through their open source journey. To know more about mentorship, refer here : https://girlscriptsummerofcode.github.io/MentorshipProgram/ To register as a mentor, fill this form : http://bit.ly/mentorGSSOC If you have your own open source project and you wish to make it part of GirlScript Summer of Code, you can fill this form: http://bit.ly/ProjectsGSSOC #OpenSource #GSSoC

To know more about mentorship, refer here : https://girlscriptsummerofcode.github.io/MentorshipProgram/ To register as a mentor, fill this form : http://bit.ly/mentorGSSOC If you have your own open source project and you wish to make it part of GirlScript Summer of Code, you can fill this form: http://bit.ly/ProjectsGSSOC #OpenSource #GSSoC

message:
Results of Freshers Selections

For the past couple of weeks, we were in the process of recruiting people who will take Kharagpur Open Source Society forward in the upcoming academic session. Buoyed by the participation of current 1st-year students, we have rigorously vetted and discussed each person who interviewed with us. Having said this, we believe that any selection process(including our’s) should not be considered as the sole criteria to judge one’s own self-worth as a programmer. Each one of us is a diamond underneath the surface. Thus, we would like to congratulate everyone who worked on their tasks after interviews and presented it to us.

We welcome the following individuals to the KOSS team:

Aaryan Bhagat
Aditya Vikram Singh
Anushka Shukla
Arnav Tiwari
Gaurav Goyal
Gurjot Singh Suri
Kousshik Raj
Mansi Sinha
Navaneeth S
Nikhil Choudhary
Pankhuri Saxena
Piyush Ranjan
Praagy Rastogi
Ritik Kumar
Sanket Kumar Singh
Shivam Kumar Jha
Shreyas Kowshik
Shruti Shevya
Taapas Agrawal
Vedprakash
Vivek Raj
Yash Sharma

Institute Wellness Group, IIT Kharagpur, IIT Kharagpur in association with Metakgp, Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS and Lean In, IIT Kharagpur is organizing "KGP Developers Meet" to bring all the developing enthusiasts on campus under a single umbrella to discuss on projects for the betterment of the KGP Community!
Come forward to hear from faculty, experienced coders and student representatives! A funda session follows post!
Have a jest of this part of the world from the best in their domain!
See you all at 5pm on 18th March 2018 in S.N. Bose Auditorium, Main Building!
Spread the word!

“Coming together is a beginning; keeping together is progress; working together is success.” — Henry Ford
The time has come for Freshers to convert their zeal for Open Source to actually seeing it happen. And it happens when you you work as a team. KOSS is looking for freshers motivated and inspired towards spreading the word of open source.
There is a change in the dates for selection.
We are having our selections on 14th and 15th March from 6:30 PM to 10:30 PM.
Venue : F243 & F244 , First Floor, Main Building
Register on the link given below - 
https://tinyurl.com/koss2018
See you there🙂

Hello Freshers.
Have used Open Sourced tools? Loved the idea of "free"?
Wanna spread this movement? Then it's the time of the year again when we look for motivated and enthusiastic people with a love for Open Source and committed to the FOSS movement!
We at Kharagpur Open Source Society do our part in the campus, while we have achieved a bit, a lot has to be done and we must keep this wheel rolling, be a part of us, be a part of this movement!
To know more join us in V3 Vikramshila complex at 7:15pm for our introductory Seminar! Check out the poster for more details.
See you all there.
Date: 07:15PM
Time: 12-03-2018
Veunu: Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS

Intuit India is visiting IIT Kharagpur this weekend to conduct a workshop on maintaining large scale Open Source projects and hands-on exercises at writing microservices & web APIs with the distinguished engineer, Peter Thomas - the creator of Karate (One of Intuit's popular open source projects on Github). Students from 2nd and 3rd year (4th if pre-final) are welcome to participate.

Participants can expect to win FREE SWAG, PRIZES and open up INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES at Intuit this summer! 😄

Feel free to ping us if you have any questions.

Date: Feb 3rd, 2018 (Saturday)
Time: 3 PM - 8 PM
Venue: NR 321 & 322

Registration link: https://goo.gl/forms/yB9X8JtO2bmltJaF3

We successfully conducted an introductory workshop on GSoC wherein we had invited speakers who were selected as students as well as mentors in GSoC. They shared their experiences, benefits, tips, and advice on how to participate in the open source culture! Thanks to all of the speakers as well as those who attended!

message:
20th Jan (Tomorrow) | NR223 | 2:00 PM

"It will not be an overstatement to say that Go will be the server language of the future."

Go, is an Open Source Programming language created at Google, created with system design in mind. It is statically typed which enables it to gain speed comparable to C/C++ but with the ease of dynamic language syntax. Read more on why should you learn Go[1].

And if you already know about this, how about removing the to-do "Learn Go" from your mind and do that tomorrow itself at 2PM?

Venue: NR223, Nalanda

https://medium.com/@kevalpatel2106/why-should-you-learn-go-f607681fad65

GSoC 2018 Introductory Seminar   Himanshu Patankar

Yes, it is that time of the year again when you have to convert coffee to code. I hope you all know that Google Summer of Code is approaching soon and the Selected Organization list is going to be published on Feb 12.
Therefore, we are planning to conduct a seminar on how to overcome the initial barrier and we will also provide you a lot of insights about GSoC program by people who have cracked GSoC before as students and as mentors. The mentors will provide you even better insights of how they select students and much more stuff.
Thus we hope to see you for the GSoC seminar on

Date: Wednesday, 17th January
Time: 6.00pm
Venue: Kalidas Auditorium

https://www.facebook.com/events/1720330664673281/
Cheers!

The countdown is over! Kharagpur Winter of Code is now taking student registrations.

https://kwoc.kossiitkgp.in

KWoC is a December long online program. For those who already know about Google Summer of Code, KWoC is going to be very helpful for you. Register yourself as a student and the instructions will follow you. For those who don't know about such open source programs, KWoC is a platform where you are going to learn about a new style of collaborative software development. Read more on the website.

In simple steps:
- Register yourself.
- Go through the projects.
- Choose one/two you want to work on.
- Contact the mentor of the project.
- Contribute !

Feel free to reach us anytime.

With ❤️

Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS shared Metakgp's post. Kharagpur Winter of Code has been announced for one more time. Started last year, it is a program to introduce new students to free and open-source softwares. This has also helps college students prepare for Google Summer of Code, to be held in March. For mentors : Do you maintain project(s) which needs students' contribution? Or are you a collaborator of any open source software? message:
We are happy to announce that we are hosting Kharagpur Winter of Code (KWoC) 2017, in association with Kshitij, IIT Kharagpur, this December to help students (it doesn't matter who you are as long as you are willing to learn) make their first real contributions to open source projects. We also invite enthusiastic mentors from all places to guide and share their knowledge and help students.

This is kind of a mock GSoC program tailored for beginners.

Mentors can register their projects on our official KWoC website http://kwoc.kossiitkgp.in/

Recently, we conducted a workshop at Nalanda, where we taught students the importance of Version Control System, and the usage of Git and Github. We also taught how to contribute to someone else's projects.

To revise the workshop:
1. Introduction to linux command line - Udacity (https://in.udacity.com/course/linux-command-line-basics--ud595)
2. Git and GitHub - Udacity (https://in.udacity.com/course/how-to-use-git-and-github--ud775)

To learn more than was taught in the workshop specifically about viewing older versions, modifying histories and many more tools like that:
1. Git atlassian tutorial (https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials)
2. Git-scm (https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2)  
3. Git Interactive Practice(https://learngitbranching.js.org/)

Also, here are a few glimpses from the workshop!

Kharagpur Open Source Society is conducting another workshop on Git and Github.

Time: 3.30 PM
Venue: NR122
Date: 15th October 2017 (Sunday)

In this workshop, we will teach you the basics of Git as a version control software and we will tell you how to actually contribute to projects on Github. There will be a hands-on session too, where you will learn to actually contribute to real software.

This will be a very crucial workshop for participating in Kharagpur Winter of Code which is coming soon :)

P.S. : Everyone should bring their laptops!

message:
Kharagpur Open Source Society is organizing the Ubuntu Install Fest, an opportunity to get Linux installed on your PC.

Date:   2nd September 2017
Time:   2 PM
Venue: Room 120, CSE Department

Bring out the open source geek in you by switching to Linux as a standalone OS, or get it dual booted alongside Windows.

  We'll also discuss any doubts which you may have in Python just after the fest.

Note: Please download a copy of Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (https://www.ubuntu.com/download/desktop/thank-you?country=IN&version=16.04.3&architecture=amd64). Backup all your important files and don't forget to bring a pendrive along with your laptop. Ensure there is around 100 GB free space on your PC. Make sure your laptop is fully charged for the installation to complete smoothly.
Dual boot instructions: https://wiki.metakgp.org/w/How_to_install_Ubuntu_as_Dual_Boot
PS: If you can't download Ubuntu or bring a pendrive with you, just come with your laptop, we'll have few spare pendrives.

Now that you have written an awesome software, it is probably good to make it worth reading it too. Writing good READMEs can attract more users for your open source software as well as more contributors.

One of our Executive Heads (Pranit Bauva) goes ahead to describe what makes a good README.

We had successfully conducted an introductory workshop on GSoC wherein we had invited speakers who were selected as students as well as mentors in GSoC. They shared their experiences, benefits, tips and advice on how to participate in the open source culture! Thanks to all of the speakers (Pranit Bauva, Himanshu Mishra, Avijit Ghosh, Nishant Nikhil, Sampad Saha, Anchit Navelkar, Shivam Vats, Ayush Pandey, Harsh Gupta, Pranay Yadav, Abinash Meher) as well as those who attended!

message:
Greetings !

We are sharing the highlights from the GSoC session yesterday for those who could not attend. This[1] is the link of our presentation.

Please join Klug on Slack[2] by inviting your self from here - https://klug-slack.herokuapp.com
Join the #gsoc channel and introduce yourself in a line or two. You can find a lot of GSoCers from KGP[3] over there, so don't hesitate.

We had mentioned about FLOSS Manuals[4] for the students. You must give this a read. It is written in a very simple and lucid manner and is one of the most useful resources for you right now.

You should also give a light read to a classic article on How to Ask Smart Questions[5]. And this is not just for GSoC !

And finally, here are a bunch of resources for you to learn Git[6], which you would be using later.

Email us or ask on KLUG slack for any help that we can provide. Do not hesitate. :)

[1] https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1c5FZLeNqGvcG4xRVK2BVI0nKAbQqCWMJrxcWBSEKR74 
[2] https://klug.slack.com 
[3] https://wiki.metakgp.org/w/Google_Summer_of_Code 
[4] http://write.flossmanuals.net/gsocstudentguide/what-is-google-summer-of-code/
[5] http://www.catb.org/~esr/faqs/smart-questions.html
[6] https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Jsun1_rU4VcK9N059NZyO3GcG9qI1LJgazoj5lSre5E

Cheers !

Yes, it is that time of the year again when you have to convert coffee to code. I hope you all know that Google Summer of Code is approaching soon and the Selected Organization list is going to be published on coming Monday.
Therefore, we are planning to conduct a seminar on how to overcome the initial barrier and we will also provide you a lot of insights about GSoC program by people who have cracked GSoC before as students and as mentors. The mentors will provide you even better insights of how they select students and much more stuff.
Thus we hope to see you for the GSoC seminar on Monday, 27th February 2017 at 6.30pm Vikramshila V4.
Cheers!
Date: 06:30PM
Time: 27-02-2017
Veunu: Vikramshila, IIT Kharagpur

First practical attack on SHA-1 shown by CWI/Google Research!
This should not come as a surprise to anyone - the theoretical problem has been known for years.
If you haven't already made sure to switch VPNs, certificates, SSH services and whatnot to SHA-2, now is a good time!

Read more at http://shattered.io/
